data.title: Prospect Report: Elly De La Cruz Is Incredible
data.meta_description: The Reds' top prospect posted a night for the ages against Columbus.
data.meta_site_name: College Baseball, MLB Draft, Prospects - Baseball America
data.text:
Image credit: Elly De La Cruz (Photo by Dylan Buell/Getty Images)

Elly De La Cruz, SS, Reds: On Tuesday, Cincinnati’s top prospect put together one of the most absurd nights in recent memory. In his first three at-bats, he slammed a double and two home runs—one from each side of the plate. On its own, that’s a fantastic evening. Thanks to the publicly available Hawk-Eye data, we know exactly how hard De La Cruz crushed each pitch.

In his second at-bat, facing Luis Oviedo, he throttled a slider 456 feet just to the left of dead-center field. The home run was hit 116.6 mph. It was the softest of his three hits on the evening.

An inning later, against Phillip Diehl, De La Cruz did it again. This time he got a 93 mph fastball and crushed it a mere 428 feet, roughly to the same spot his first home run landed. The exit velocity on that one? 117.1 mph. And it still wasn’t the hardest ball he hit in the game.

To find De La Cruz’s loudest contact, you have to rewind the game to the second inning, when he was pitted against Columbus’ Adam Scott. The lefty dealt a sinker. De La Cruz capitalized, sending a double into the left-field corner that left the bat at an absurd 118.8 mph.

As if the hard contact weren’t enough, De La Cruz keeping the ball in the park meant he got to show off his elite speed. He reached 28.7 feet per second while motoring to second base, good for the fourth-fastest sprint speed of the game.

After a night of crushing baseballs, De La Cruz performed his final trick without taking the bat off his shoulder. With the bases loaded and the game tied in the bottom of the ninth, he took four straight pitches from reliever Jason Bilous, the last a changeup just below the knees, to work a game-winning walk.

In total, De La Cruz finished the evening 3-for-4 with a double, two home runs, four RBIs and two walks.

What a night. What a prospect.

Austin Wells, Jasson Dominguez, Everson Pereira, Yankees: With Wells back after an early-season injury, three of New York’s best prospects now occupy the same Somerset lineup. On Tuesday, they batted in the second, third and fourth spots and quickly showed hints of their upside.

All three players hit home runs in the opening game of the team’s series with Portland, and Dominguez and Wells each finished the game 2-for-5 with a pair of runs and RBIs. Combined, the trio went 5-for-15 with a double (Wells), three home runs, five RBIs, five runs and six strikeouts.

Henry Davis, C, Pirates: Perhaps the key to Davis getting the most out of his skills is to simply stay healthy. He’s done so this year, and the results have followed. On Tuesday, the 2021 No. 1 overall pick swatted two home runs in Double-A Altoona’s series opener with Erie. The blasts were Davis’ seventh and eighth of the season, meaning that through 21 games he’s already two-thirds of the way to his career home run total entering the year.

Jose Peroza, 3B, Mets: Entering the night, the 22-year-old Peroza had two home runs. After Tuesday’s game was final, that total had jumped to five. For those following along on your trusty abacus, that means Peroza hit three home runs in Binghamton’s loss to Hartford. The outburst was Peroza’s first multi-home run game since July 11, 2019, when he went deep twice for the GCL Mets.

Andres Chaparro, 3B, Yankees: Chaparro’s game revolves around hitting the ball a very long way. He homered once on Tuesday, but that doesn’t tell the whole story. The longball—Chaparro’s 10th of the season—was part of a 5-for-5 evening against Omaha. Chaparro finished a triple shy of the cycle and drove in four runs.
